Title: Linking forum posts -medicalneuro-002-2-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Lateralisation of thalamocortical and corticothalamic projections
Input.posts:
Both from somatosensory and visual pathways, it seems the thalamic nuclei project to the ipsilateral part of cortex (postcentral gyrus and V1 respectively). Is this correct, or are there contralateral projections too? Similarly, can feedback afferents from cortex to thalamus project both ipsilaterally and contralaterally, or is there a specific organisation for these connections? Finally, I think I've asked on a different thread where do the nonspecific nuclei of the thalamus receive inputs from, but may I please repeat and expand that question: Do non-specific thalamic nuclei also receive feedback input from the cortex? And is there organisation in the inputs/outputs of these nonspecific nuclei, in terms of reciprocity of connections (with cortical neurons) and lateralisation? As always, many thanks to anyone who might answer.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
More great questions! Thanks, Ana. You should know that the thalamus provides projections to the ipsilateral cerebral cortex. There may be some exceptional contralateral projections from some thalamic neurons, but I have never seen such in my own anatomical research and certainly you should take away that ipsilateral projections -- if they exist -- are the rare exception, rather than the rule. The non-specific thalamic nuclei also receive input from cortex, but they also receive input from others sources as well, including the pallidum of the basal ganglia and certain brainstem nuclei. Despite their common name (non-specific), there is some topographic organization to their connections; just not nearly as tight a topography as with the so-called 'specific' nuclei of the thalamus.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Kristian raises an excellent question that highlights on ongoing problem in human neuroanatomy: despite some attempt to standardize nomenclature, there are various terms floating about for some of the pathways that are of interest to us in Medical Neuroscience. In this case, I specifically use the term 'trigeminal lemniscus' (rather than trigeminothalamic tract) to refer to the projections from the principal or chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal complex to the contralateral ventral posterior medial nucleus of the thalamus. Please note that these axons convey mechanosensations originating in the face to the contralateral thalamus. The term 'lemniscus' highlights two aspects of this system that are worth remembering: (1) that this is a mechanosensory pathway just like the medial lemniscus for the post cranial body; and (2) that these axons run just medial to the medial lemniscus and provide a 'head' (hemi-head, really) for the 'headless' homonculus conveyed in the medial lemniscus. So I would encourage all of us to use the term 'trigeminal lemniscus' when referring to these second-order axons of the cranial touch (mechanosensory) system. I would also encourage us to restrict the term 'trigeminothalamic tract' to the second order axons of the spinal trigeminal nucleus that convey pain and temperature signals to the contralateral VPM thalamus. This term (trigeminothalamic) should emphasize that this pathway is the cranial counterpart to the spinothalamic tract, which conveys pain and temperature signals from the dorsal horn of the spinal cord (concerning the post cranial body) to the contralateral VPL thalamus. When I was a graduate student (many moons ago!), I learned these pathways by their older names: -- dorsal trigeminothalamic tract = trigeminal lemnsicus (mechanosensation) -- ventral trigeminothalamic tract = trigeminothalamic tract (pain and temperature) I find it quite happier to drop the 'dorsal' and 'ventral' and emphasize terms that remind me of the parallelism between the pathways for the cranial region and the post cranial body. Hope this helps to address Kristian's original question!

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Are you asking about muscle cramps? Perhaps you are referring to fasciculations or fibrillations, but I will assume you are referring to what we commonly call muscle cramps. I'm not a muscle physiologist, but we can imagine that depolarization of the sacrolemma would lead to the kind of spasmodic contractions that occur during a painful muscle cramp (I get them in the intrinsic muscle of my feet on a regular basis, and sometimes in my calf muscles). [Incidentally, have you heard of the 'home remedy' of taking a small swallow of mustard to terminate the cramping and/or prevent it? It is also claimed that a bar of soap in the bed sheets will prevent night time cramps (really!).] My understanding of these phenomena is that they have more to do with the excitability of the muscle fiber than the activity of the motor neurons that innervate them. Thus, conditions that depolarize muscle fiber (e.g., reduction in potassium gradient) or alter calcium homeostasis are likely to induce the spasmodic contractions.

Input.posts:
I'm rewatching the videos in Unit 4 and beginning to understand the reflexes. I am curious: what happens muscles sometimes contract spasmodically, and cannot be stretched without effort? Does the Golgi tendon fail to signal the increased force and generate automatic stretch? Is this, perhaps, because the membrane is depolarised, but not enough to reach action potential threshold? Common wisdom is that it these spasms might be related to Ca deficit, is it that there is not enough extracellular Ca to depolarise the cell enough so that an action potential would be fired? Another common wisdom relates spasms with damage to the joint, is it, in that case, that the intermingling of Golgi tendon organ with fibers is compromised, so that a contraction in some part of the muscle fails to activate the ionic channels? Or - what are the causes, if not those I speculated about?
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Are you asking about muscle cramps? Perhaps you are referring to fasciculations or fibrillations, but I will assume you are referring to what we commonly call muscle cramps. I'm not a muscle physiologist, but we can imagine that depolarization of the sacrolemma would lead to the kind of spasmodic contractions that occur during a painful muscle cramp (I get them in the intrinsic muscle of my feet on a regular basis, and sometimes in my calf muscles). [Incidentally, have you heard of the 'home remedy' of taking a small swallow of mustard to terminate the cramping and/or prevent it? It is also claimed that a bar of soap in the bed sheets will prevent night time cramps (really!).] My understanding of these phenomena is that they have more to do with the excitability of the muscle fiber than the activity of the motor neurons that innervate them. Thus, conditions that depolarize muscle fiber (e.g., reduction in potassium gradient) or alter calcium homeostasis are likely to induce the spasmodic contractions.

Input.threadtitle: How cerebellar firing patterns modulate movement
Input.posts:
Hi guys, I've just watch the cerebellum tutorials from unit 4. I found them quite good for giving an overview of the cerebellum but I'm struggling to get my head around how the inhibition from Purkinje cells and the excitation from the granule cell branches combine to influence the deep nuclei. The way I think I understand it, the deep cerebellar nuclei will fire quickly to indicate an error. Is there a different rate of firing that indicates normal function? Or is normal function typified by the inhibitory signal from the Purkinje cell? If anybody knows of any good sources that can help shed some light on this obviously confusing subject, and the extent of current knowledge on how the cerebellum works, that'd be fantastic. Thanks, Alex
Upvotes:
0
I also struggle a lot with this process. I understand all the components of the circuit such as Purkinje cells being inhibitory and receiving the exitatory input from the mossy cells and the climbing fibers; as well as mossy fibers and climbing fibers contributing exitatory input to the deep nuclei, and the stellate, basket and Golgi cells 'inhibiting the inhibitory Purkinje cells', but how does the actual learning happen? I re-read the relevant paragraphs in the neuroscience a number of times, but struggle to grasp the concept. Please help.
Upvotes:
1
This is how I imagine the process might happen, based on the anatomy we've learned (but whoever has more insight, please chip in): Frontal and parietal send move intention to CBL via mossy fibers from pontine nuclei; these would provide the deep nuclei with fast excitation and delayed and possibly scaled down inhibition (via Purkinje cells). The spinal cord and vestibular nuclei send information (via mossy fibers) about the movements actually executed (by body and head respectively). Again these would provide fast excitation and delayed inhibition to deep nuclei. But movement intention precedes movement execution. In a sense, we can imagine that the inhibition from the initial movement intention arrives at the same time as the excitation from the resulting movement; and the inhibition from the executed movement arrives at the same time as the excitation about the movement planned next. So we might simplistically, in a very rough first approximation, imagine the output of the cerebellum being a difference between intention and execution, and between past movement and next intention. This would fit in with the role of cerebellum in sequences of movements. The inferior olive sends timing signals via the climbing fibers; these signals presumably 'pair' correctly movement intentions with sensory information. Now, from what I remember from the lectures, I think plasticity takes place at the level of Purkinje cells, not in the deep nuclei. At the level of the Purkinje cell, both movement intention and sensory feedback are excitatory. A very simplistic way of picturing this might be that whenever the total excitation to Purkinje cells is large enough, and the climbing fibers from the inferior olive have decided that this total excitation comes from summing the correct signals (eg the movement intention and movement execution for the same action), the inputs to the Purkinje cells are weighted down, so that the output of the deep nuclei becomes larger. One use for this might be to increase the sensitivity of the cerebellum when errors become smaller, but there will be timing components as well (once we learn a sequence the delay between intention and execution probably decreases; however if there are errors then movement may need to be slowed down). Of course, this is an absurdly simplistic explanation, things are much more complex and beautifully tuned and regulated, but perhaps it might give an intuition. I would welcome discussion - might my overly-simplified model be anywhere close to reality, or am I misinterpreting/overlooking/imagining things?
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Thank you for the questions and Ana, thank you for the thoughtful reply. The real answer here is that no one knows (really!) how this works. The basic idea is that there is a temporal code in the firing rate and pattern of discharge coming out of the deep nuclei back toward circuits of upper motor neurons (via the thalamus and brainstem circuits). This 'code' is modulated or modified by the input of the Purkinje neurons. One of the world's leading experts on the deep cerebellar nuclei (WT Thach) explained it to me in terms of how the discharge pattern of the deep nuclei gets 'chopped' by the descending inhibitory inputs of the Purkinje neurons. Evidently, as cortical plasticity weakens this 'chopping' activity, the output of the deep nuclei strengthens and the temporal signature of this activity may now convey the long postulated 'error signal' that facilitates coordination of sequential multi-jointed movement. I like Ana's speculations on the timing of all of this. This very well may be a helpful way to consider how the output of the cerebellum contributes to adjusting the next phase/cycle of movement. I wish I could speak on this topic with greater insight and authority, but I'm afraid that the science has just not yet led to the breakthroughs that we need to provide a more complete explanation of how the cerebellum promotes agility of body and mind. Thanks again for the interesting discussion on this topic.

Cells derived from common precursor cells develop different physical characteristics (phenotypically) because their exposure to different environmental conditions (chemical signalling), either in space or time, has induced different patterns of gene expression. Professor White tends to address this issue in the Early Brain Development lectures.

Cells derived from common precursor cells develop different physical characteristics (phenotypically) because their exposure to different environmental conditions (chemical signalling), either in space or time, has induced different patterns of gene expression. For example, chemical signals from the notochord induce changes (via gene expression) in the overlying ectoderm to form the neural plate, which, over time, will form all the cells of the nervous system. Cells located in other parts of the ectoderm, which are exposed to different chemical signals, will go on to form the cells of the skin. Professor White tends to address this issue in the Early Brain Development lectures.
